1.text: I say then, Did God cast off his people? God forbid. For I also am an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.

2.text: God did not cast off his people which he foreknew. Or wot ye not what the scripture saith of Elijah? how he pleadeth with God against Israel,

3.text: Lord, they have killed thy prophets, they have digged down thine altars: and I am left alone, and they seek my life.

4.text: But what saith the answer of God unto him? I have left for myself seven thousand men, who have not bowed the knee to Baal.

5.text: Even so then at this present time also there is a remnant according to the election of grace.

6.text: But if it is by grace, it is no more of works: otherwise grace is no more grace.

7.text: What then? That which Israel seeketh for, that he obtained not; but the election obtained it, and the rest were hardened:

8.text: according as it is written, God gave them a spirit of stupor, eyes that they should not see, and ears that they should not hear, unto this very day.

9.text: And David saith, Let their table be made a snare, and a trap, And a stumblingblock, and a recompense unto them:

10.text: Let their eyes be darkened, that they may not see, And bow thou down their back alway.

11.text: I say then, Did they stumble that they might fall? God forbid: but by their fall salvation is come unto the Gentiles, for to provoke them to jealousy.

12.text: Now if their fall is the riches of the world, and their loss the riches of the Gentiles; how much more their fulness?

13.text: But I speak to you that are Gentiles. Inasmuch then as I am an apostle of Gentiles, I glorify my ministry:

14.text: if by any means I may provoke to jealousy them that are my flesh, and may save some of them.

15.text: For if the casting away of them is the reconciling of the world, what shall the receiving of them be, but life from the dead?

16.text: And if the firstfruit is holy, so is the lump: and if the root is holy, so are the branches.

17.text: But if some of the branches were broken off, and thou, being a wild olive, wast grafted in among them, and didst become partaker with them of the root of the fatness of the olive tree;

18.text: glory not over the branches: but if thou gloriest, it is not thou that bearest the root, but the root thee.

19.text: Thou wilt say then, Branches were broken off, that I might be grafted in.

20.text: Well; by their unbelief they were broken off, and thou standest by thy faith. Be not highminded, but fear:

21.text: for if God spared not the natural branches, neither will he spare thee.

22.text: Behold then the goodness and severity of God: toward them that fell, severity; but toward thee, God’s goodness, if thou continue in his goodness: otherwise thou also shalt be cut off.

23.text: And they also, if they continue not in their unbelief, shall be grafted in: for God is able to graft them in again.

24.text: For if thou wast cut out of that which is by nature a wild olive tree, and wast grafted contrary to nature into a good olive tree: how much more shall these, which are the natural branches, be grafted into their own olive tree?

25.text: For I would not, brethren, have you ignorant of this mystery, lest ye be wise in your own conceits, that a hardening in part hath befallen Israel, until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in;

26.text: and so all Israel shall be saved: even as it is written, There shall come out of Zion the Deliverer; He shall turn away ungodliness from Jacob:

27.text: And this is my covenant unto them, When I shall take away their sins.

28.text: As touching the gospel, they are enemies for your sake: but as touching the election, they are beloved for the fathers’ sake.

29.text: For the gifts and the calling of God are without repentance.

30.text: For as ye in time past were disobedient to God, but now have obtained mercy by their disobedience,

31.text: even so have these also now been disobedient, that by the mercy shewn to you they also may now obtain mercy.

32.text: For God hath shut up all unto disobedience, that he might have mercy upon all.

33.text: O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and the knowledge of God! how unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past tracing out!

34.text: For who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath been his counsellor?

35.text: or who hath first given to him, and it shall be recompensed unto him again?

36.text: For of him, and through him, and unto him, are all things. To him be the glory for ever. Amen.
